questions.text:
Which of the following vaccines is generally not recommended for individuals over 65 years of age? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Hepatitis B
  2. Influenza
  3. Human papillomavirus (HPV)
  4. Pneumococcal
questions.solution:
Ans. B) c only

 

HPV vaccine is not recommended for individuals over 65 years of age because it is only approved for use up to 45 years of age. The other vaccines mentioned can be safely and effectively administered to elderly individuals based on their risk factors and previous vaccination status.

 

Other Options:

 

a. Hepatitis B vaccine: This is conditionally indicated in elderly individuals who have not previously received the vaccine and have risk factors.

 

b. Influenza vaccine: This is strongly recommended annually for elderly individuals as they are at high risk for complications from influenza infection.

 

d. Pneumococcal vaccine: This is a crucial vaccine for elderly individuals. The current recommendation in India is to give PCV13 followed by PPSV23 to provide comprehensive protection against pneumococcal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The age-based restrictions for HPV vaccination (approved only up to age 45) and the core vaccines recommended for elderly individuals (pneumococcal, influenza, and conditional hepatitis B vaccination).

 

The only non-recommended vaccine in this list for those over 65 years is HPV, while pneumococcal, influenza, and hepatitis B vaccines may all be indicated based on individual risk factors and previous vaccination status.

questions.text: Nadas criteria include all of the following except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Raised Trop T level

 

Nadas criteria, proposed by Hungarian cardiologist Dr. Alexander Nadas in the 1950s–60s, are used for diagnosing congenital heart disease. The criteria require at least one major and two minor criteria for diagnosis. Major criteria include systolic murmur grade 3-4/6, diastolic murmur, presence of congestive heart failure, and cyanosis. Minor criteria include grade 2/6 systolic murmur, abnormal S2, abnormal chest X-ray, abnormal ECG, and abnormal blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nadas criteria are used for diagnosing congenital heart disease, which includes both major criteria (systolic murmur grade 3-4/6, diastolic murmur, CCF, cyanosis) and minor criteria (grade 2/6 systolic murmur, abnormal S2, abnormal X-ray, abnormal ECG, abnormal BP).

choices.text: Nelson syndrome
Sheehan syndrome
Conn's syndrome

questions.text: A woman comes with complaints of hyperpigmentation of her palms after an adrenalectomy. She also has new onset vision deficits. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nelson syndrome

 

Explanation:  

 

Nelson syndrome occurs in patients who have undergone bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's disease due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. After the adrenalectomy, the absence of cortisol feedback leads to increased secretion of ACTH by the pituitary adenoma. This results in:

 

  • Hyperpigmentation: Due to elevated levels of ACTH and its precursor, which stimulates melanocytes.
  • Vision deficits: Caused by the growth of the pituitary adenoma, which can compress the optic chiasma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sheehan syndrome: Caused by postpartum necrosis of the pituitary gland, leading to hypopituitarism. It presents with failure to lactate, amenorrhea, and hypothyroidism, but not with hyperpigmentation or vision deficits post-adrenalectomy.

 

Option C. Conn's syndrome: Primary hyperaldosteronism, characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. It does not cause hyperpigmentation or vision deficits.

 

Option D. Addison's disease:  Primary adrenal insufficiency presenting with hyperpigmentation due to high ACTH, but it is not typically associated with vision deficits or occurring after adrenalectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nelson syndrome is characterized by hyperpigmentation and vision deficits following bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's disease, due to the growth of an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma.

questions.text: A patient presented with recurrent Raynaud’s phenomenon. She also complained of thickening of skin in the hands and difficulty in swallowing. What is the diagnosis and immunofluorescence pattern shown? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti-centromere pattern; Systemic sclerosis

 

The combination of Raynaud's phenomenon, skin thickening limited to hands (acral areas), and difficulty swallowing points to limited systemic sclerosis (formerly called CREST syndrome). The immunofluorescence image shows a characteristic centromeric pattern with discrete speckles corresponding to centromeres in dividing cells. Anti-centromere antibodies are specifically associated with limited systemic sclerosis, making this pattern diagnostic in this clinical context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nuclear pattern; SLE: Incorrect. The pattern shown is centromeric, not nuclear.

 

Option B. Homogeneous pattern; SLE: Incorrect. Homogeneous patterns are produced by anti-histone and anti-dsDNA antibodies, seen in SLE or drug-induced lupus.

 

Option C. Speckled pattern; Systemic sclerosis: Incorrect. While speckled patterns can be seen in systemic sclerosis (particularly with anti-Scl-70 antibodies in diffuse disease), the image shows a centromeric pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-centromere antibodies producing a centromeric immunofluorescence pattern are specifically associated with limited systemic sclerosis, particularly when presenting with Raynaud's phenomenon and acral skin thickening.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with weight loss, mediastinal lymphadenopathy, and pleural effusion. Her HRCT shows a "tree-in-bud" pattern, indicating lung consolidation and effusion. Analysis of pleural fluid reveals high adenosine deaminase (ADA) levels with a predominance of lymphocytes. What is the most likely finding on lymph node biopsy? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Necrotizing epithelioid granuloma

 

This is a classic presentation of tuberculosis (TB):

 

  • "Tree-in-bud" appearance on HRCT indicates endobronchial spread — a hallmark of active pulmonary TB.
  • Mediastinal lymphadenopathy and pleural effusion with lymphocyte predominance further support a tuberculous etiology.
  • High ADA (>40 U/L) in pleural fluid is a strong indicator of TB pleuritis.

 

The most characteristic lymph node biopsy finding in TB is:

 

  • Necrotizing (caseating) epithelioid granulomas
  •  Composed of epithelioid cells (from activated macrophages), Langhans giant cells, and central caseous necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fungal hyphae surrounded by lymphocytes:  Seen in invasive fungal infections (e.g., aspergillosis, histoplasmosis), more common in immunocompromised individuals; not typically associated with high ADA.

 

Option B. Anthracosis pigment: Black carbon pigment in lungs/lymph nodes from pollution or smoking. Not pathological in itself and doesn’t cause systemic symptoms or effusion.

 

Option D. Reactive hyperplasia: Seen in viral or nonspecific bacterial infections. No granulomas or caseation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a young woman with systemic symptoms, tree-in-bud pattern, lymphocytic pleural effusion, and high ADA, TB is the most likely diagnosis. The hallmark histopathological finding is a necrotizing epithelioid granuloma.

choices.text: Initiate targeted temperature management of <33°C, if the patient is confused
Perform emergent cardiac intervention if ST elevation is present in the ECG
Maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65 mmHg

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the management of patients who have achieved return of spontaneous circulation following CPR? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Initiate targeted temperature management of <33°C, if the patient is confused

 

In post-resuscitation care after return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC), targeted temperature management (TTM) should be maintained between 33–36°C, not below 33°C. Lower temperatures increase the risk of coagulopathy, bleeding, and infections like pneumonia. For patients with high bleeding risk or coagulopathy, the target should be 36–37.5°C.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Target SpO₂ >94%: Initially, target SpO₂ should be >92%, and once intubated and on mechanical ventilation, the target should be >94%. Overall target range is 92–98%.

 

Option C. Perform emergent cardiac intervention if ST elevation is present in the ECG: If STEMI is identified as the cause of cardiac arrest, immediate cardiac catheterization should be performed within 2 hours as it's a reversible cause.

 

Option D. Maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65 mmHg: This is the minimum MAP that should be achieved using vasopressors and IV fluids. The ideal MAP range is 80–100 mmHg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In post-resuscitation care after ROSC, targeted temperature management should be maintained between 33–36°C, with higher targets (36–37.5°C) for patients at risk of bleeding or coagulopathy. Temperature should never be targeted below 33°C due to increased complications.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be used to differentiate psoriatic arthritis from other conditions? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence of diarrhea

 

Diarrhea cannot reliably differentiate psoriatic arthritis from other forms of arthritis because it can be present in multiple arthritic conditions. Diarrhea could indicate:

 

  • Reactive arthritis following gastrointestinal infection
  • Inflammatory bowel disease-associated arthritis
  • Post-viral arthritis
  • Other forms of seronegative spondyloarthropathies

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enthesitis:

 

  • Enthesitis (inflammation at sites where tendons/ligaments insert into bone) is a characteristic feature of psoriatic arthritis
  • It helps differentiate psoriatic arthritis from other forms like rheumatoid arthritis

 

Option C. Dactylitis:

 

  • Dactylitis ("sausage digits") is highly characteristic of psoriatic arthritis
  • Represents inflammation of the entire digit with soft tissue swelling
  • Helps differentiate from other forms where dactylitis is uncommon

 

Option D. Nail pitting:

 

  • Nail changes are seen in 80–90% of psoriatic arthritis patients
  • Nail pitting is a characteristic finding that helps distinguish psoriatic arthritis
  • A valuable diagnostic feature when present

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enthesitis, dactylitis, and nail changes are characteristic features that help diagnose psoriatic arthritis. Diarrhea is a nonspecific symptom that can occur in multiple forms of arthritis and cannot be used as a differentiating feature.

choices.text: BP should be checked multiple times before administering anti-hypertensives
In haemorrhagic stroke, you should aggressively treat with intravenous anti-hypertensives
In haemorrhagic stroke, BP should be reduced to 160/100 mmHg with anti-hypertensives
BP should be reduced immediately to less than 140/90 mmHg in ischemic stroke

questions.text: A patient presented with altered sensorium and his BP was 220/110 mmHg. He also had one episode of vomiting and on examination has weakness in the left upper and lower limbs. Which of the following is incorrect? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) BP should be reduced immediately to less than 140/90 mmHg in ischemic stroke

 

In acute ischemic stroke, blood pressure is often elevated as a physiological response to maintain perfusion to the ischemic penumbra. Unless:

 

  • The patient is receiving thrombolysis, in which case BP should be <185/110 mmHg, or
  • The BP is severely elevated (>220/120 mmHg),

 

You should not acutely lower the blood pressure. Lowering it to <140/90 mmHg immediately is contraindicated, as it can worsen cerebral hypoperfusion and enlarge the infarct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BP should be checked multiple times before administering anti-hypertensives: Correct. Rechecking BP ensures accuracy and avoids overtreatment of transient spikes. Stroke protocols depend on consistently high values.

 

Option B. In haemorrhagic stroke, you should aggressively treat with intravenous anti-hypertensives: Correct. Rapid BP control reduces ongoing bleeding and hematoma expansion. Agents like labetalol and nicardipine are preferred.

 

Option C. In haemorrhagic stroke, BP should be reduced to 160/100 mmHg with anti-hypertensives: Correct. Target BP of <160/100 mmHg is generally accepted to balance the risk of further bleeding with maintaining cerebral perfusion. Even though it is not a specific recommendation in haemorrhagic stroke, it is acceptable.

 

Trials that are important –

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The specific blood pressure targets in acute stroke:

 

  • General recommendation in hypertensive emergency: Reduce BP by 25% in 1st hour, then target around 160/100 mmHg within 2–6 hours
  • Ischemic stroke with thrombolysis: <185/110 mmHg
  • Ischemic stroke without thrombolysis: <220/120 mmHg
  • Hemorrhagic Stroke: Controversial – SBP <140 mmHg (INTERACT2) vs. 140–180 mmHg (WHO 2021)

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of HTN, DM2, and DLP is brought to the ER because of reports of palpitations and dizziness. ECG is ordered and shown in the image. His temperature is 36.8°C, PR is 106/min, RR is 18/min, BP is 84/46 mm Hg, and SpO2 is 92% on room air. What is the next step? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. DC shock

 

The patient presents with symptoms of palpitations and dizziness and is found to have an irregularly irregular rhythm on ECG, consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF). The absence of distinct P waves and the presence of fibrillatory waves further support this diagnosis.

 

The patient's vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 84/46 mm Hg, indicating hemodynamic instability. In cases of tachyarrhythmias such as AF, the management approach depends on the patient's hemodynamic status. For patients who are hemodynamically unstable, immediate intervention is required.

 

Synchronized DC cardioversion is the treatment of choice in hemodynamically unstable patients with AF. This procedure involves delivering a synchronized shock to restore normal rhythm. The shock is timed (synchronized) to occur at the peak of the R wave to avoid inducing ventricular fibrillation.

 

Specific contraindications for using synchronized direct current (DC) cardioversion (synchronized DC shocking) are sinus tachycardia, multifocal atrial tachycardia digoxin toxicity. But in cases where a patient is unstable and experiencing shock, immediate cardioversion is necessary despite these contraindications, underscoring the urgency in treating life-threatening arrhythmias in acute settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant used to prevent thromboembolic events in patients with AF. However, it is not the immediate intervention of choice for hemodynamically unstable patients. The priority in such cases is to stabilize the patient's condition, which requires electrical cardioversion.

 

Option B. Beta blocker: Beta blockers are used to control the heart rate in AF. They are not appropriate for initial management in an unstable patient, as they do not address the immediate need to restore a stable rhythm.

 

Option C. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic that can be used in the management of AF. However, it is typically used in stable patients or after electrical cardioversion has been attempted. In an unstable patient, immediate electrical cardioversion is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hemodynamically unstable patients with atrial fibrillation, immediate synchronized DC cardioversion is the next step to restore a stable rhythm and improve hemodynamic status.

choices.text: Decreased action of LPL and increased action of HSL
Increased action of LPL and increased action of HSL
Decreased action of LPL and decreased action of HSL
Increased action of LPL and decreased action of HSL

questions.text: In a patient with diabetes mellitus, the synthesis of TG and VLDL is increased from the liver. What is the cause of the same? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased action of LPL and increased action of HSL

 

In diabetes mellitus, insulin deficiency or resistance leads to two important enzymatic changes:

 

  1. Decreased activity of Lipoprotein Lipase (LPL) – This enzyme normally converts triglycerides in blood to free fatty acids for storage in adipose tissue
  2. Increased activity of Hormone Sensitive Lipase (HSL) – This promotes release of stored triglycerides as free fatty acids from adipose tissue

 

These changes result in:

 

  • Increased triglycerides in blood due to decreased LPL activity
  • Increased lipolysis and ketosis due to increased HSL activity
  • Overall increase in circulating free fatty acids

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased action of LPL and increased action of HSL: Insulin resistance/deficiency decreases LPL activity

 

Option C. Decreased action of LPL and decreased action of HSL: HSL activity is increased, not decreased in diabetes

 

Option D. Increased action of LPL and decreased action of HSL: This would increase TG clearance and decrease lipolysis, opposite to what occurs in diabetes

 

Educational Objective:

 

In diabetes mellitus, decreased LPL and increased HSL activities lead to increased triglycerides and VLDL synthesis in the liver, contributing to diabetic dyslipidemia.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with a history of dyslipidemia, hypertension, and aortic sclerosis presents to the emergency department with chest pain. He took 3 NTG tablets with no relief. His vitals are stable and cardiac enzymes were normal. An ECG on admission is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Unstable Angina

 

The patient's presentation includes chest pain unrelieved by nitroglycerin (NTG), stable vitals, and normal cardiac enzymes. The provided ECG is normal, showing no signs of ST elevation or ischemic changes such as ST depression or T wave inversion.

 

Unstable Angina involves chest pain at rest or with minimal exertion, and normal cardiac enzymes. The patient has multiple risk factors (dyslipidemia, hypertension, aortic sclerosis), and the fact that his chest pain did not respond to NTG and his enzymes are normal strongly suggests unstable angina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. STEMI: STEMI is characterized by ST elevation on ECG and elevated cardiac enzymes indicating myocardial necrosis. This patient's ECG shows no ST elevation, and his cardiac enzymes are normal, making STEMI unlikely.

 

Option B. NSTEMI: NSTEMI would present with elevated cardiac enzymes due to myocardial damage, despite the absence of ST elevation. This patient’s normal enzyme levels exclude NSTEMI.

 

Option C. Stable Angina: Stable angina presents with chest pain that is typically relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. The patient’s chest pain persisted despite taking NTG, indicating that stable angina is not the correct diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unstable angina is characterized by chest pain that occurs at rest or with minimal exertion, does not respond to nitroglycerin, and is associated with normal cardiac enzyme levels.

choices.text: Plasmapheresis is not effective in refractory GBS
IV immunoglobulins are the first line of treatment
Areflexia in the weaker arm is included in diagnostic criteria

questions.text: Regarding Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) in children, which of the following statements is false? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmapheresis is not effective in refractory GBS

 

Plasmapheresis (plasma exchange, PEX) is a well-established and effective treatment in GBS, including in refractory or severe cases. It is considered equivalent in efficacy to IVIG and may be used in patients not responding to IVIG (controversial, and sequential administration of PEX after IVIG is not recommended, but some clinicians try on a case-by-case basis), or if IVIG is contraindicated or unavailable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV immunoglobulins are the first line of treatment: Correct. IVIG can be used as first-line treatment, having equal efficacy to plasma exchange in GBS management.

 

Option C. Areflexia in the weaker arm is included in diagnostic criteria: Correct. Areflexia in the weaker arm is a mandatory diagnostic criterion according to Brighton criteria. GBS is a demyelinating disease affecting large fibers that form the basis of reflex arcs.

 

Option D. Albumino-cytological dissociation: Correct. It is a classic feature of GBS, with high protein in CSF but normal cell count (<10 cells). Any cell count >50 essentially rules out GBS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasmapheresis and IVIG are effective treatment options for GBS, including refractory cases, with neither being superior to the other. Never use immunosuppression or steroids in acute GBS.

 

 

Level of diagnostic certainty in Brighton criteria for GBS

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with a unilateral headache. It is associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. What is the best drug for acute management? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sumatriptan

 

The patient’s symptoms of unilateral headache accompanied by nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia are classic indicators of a migraine. Migraine is a common condition in young females and can be associated with other symptoms such as primary Raynaud's phenomenon.

 

For the acute management of migraines:

 

  • Mild to moderate attacks – Paracetamol or NSAIDs like Ketorolac.
  • Moderate to severe attacks - Triptans are the drugs of choice. Other group of drugs are Ditans/ Gepants
    • Sumatriptan, Rizatriptan a commonly used triptan, is a 5HT 1B/1D agonist which effectively alleviates migraine symptoms by causing vasoconstriction of the dilated blood vessels thought to be responsible for migraine pain. This action helps to reduce the headache and associated symptoms rapidly. - All of these drugs are contraindicated in the setting of pregnancy except paracetamol. Triptans are unsafe in vascular conditions
    • Ditans (Ex. Lasmiditan) are 5-HT1F receptor agonists. Unlike triptans, they do not cause vasoconstriction, making them safer for patients with vascular conditions such as coronary artery disease or peripheral arterial disease.
    • Gepents are CGRP (calcitonin gene-related peptide) antagonists or blocker. Gepents, including rimegepant, atogepant, ubrogepant, and zabigipant, are effective in migraine management. These are oral medications and do not cause vasoconstriction, which also makes them suitable for patients with certain vascular conditions.

 

Note - Dopamine Receptor Blockers: Prochlorperazine is mentioned as an example of this class. While not the focus of the discussion, dopamine receptor blockers are noted as effective in managing migraines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flunarizine: Flunarizine is a calcium channel blocker used primarily for the prophylactic (preventive) treatment of migraines, not for acute management. It helps in reducing the frequency of migraine attacks but does not relieve symptoms once an attack has started.

 

Option C. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker used for the prophylaxis of migraines. It is effective in reducing the frequency and severity of migraine attacks over time but is not used for immediate relief during an acute migraine episode.

 

Option D. Topiramate: Topiramate is an anticonvulsant medication also used for the prophylactic treatment of migraines. Similar to propranolol, it helps prevent migraines but is not effective in treating acute migraine symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sumatriptan is the drug of choice for the acute management of moderate to severe migraine attacks due to its vasoconstrictive properties and effectiveness in rapidly alleviating migraine symptoms.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive male came with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He has skin lesions as shown in the image. Chest x-ray showed multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates. His sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis was negative and he has a low CD4 count. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. HIV with disseminated histoplasmosis

 

In this case, the patient presents with persistent cough, weight loss, and skin lesions. The chest x-ray reveals multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates, and the patient has a low CD4 count. These findings are significant for several reasons:

 

Disseminated histoplasmosis can mimic tuberculosis, especially in HIV-positive patients. It causes disseminated disease with pulmonary involvement (multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates) and skin lesions. The presence of these lesions and a negative sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis further supports histoplasmosis, as this fungal infection is common in immunocompromised individuals with low CD4 counts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HIV with disseminated cryptococcosis: While cryptococcosis can cause lung disease, it more commonly presents with central nervous system involvement, such as meningitis or meningoencephalitis. This patient does not exhibit neurological symptoms, making cryptococcosis less likely.

 

Option C. HIV with molluscum contagiosum: Molluscum contagiosum causes umbilicated papules but does not lead to bilateral nodular infiltrates in the lungs. Thus, this diagnosis is unlikely given the chest x-ray findings.

 

Option D. HIV with tuberculosis: Tuberculosis is a common infection in HIV-positive patients and can present with similar symptoms and radiographic findings. However, the negative sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Educaitonal Objective:

 

Disseminated histoplasmosis in HIV-positive patients can mimic tuberculosis, presenting with pulmonary nodular infiltrates and skin lesions, especially in those with low CD4 counts.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. Investigations showed leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sarcoidosis

 

The patient presents with fever, night sweats, ptosis, and bilateral facial nerve palsy. The investigations show leukocytosis and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy.

 

Hilar lymphadenopathy can be seen in many conditions like Sarcoidosis, Pneumoconiosis, TB, etc

 

But the other clinical features point towards sarcoidosis, a systemic inflammatory disease characterized by non-caseating granulomas. Sarcoidosis can affect multiple organs, but it commonly involves the lungs and lymph nodes. Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is a hallmark finding in sarcoidosis and is often the first clue in diagnosis. Additionally, sarcoidosis can present with systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats.

 

The presence of bilateral facial nerve palsy is another significant clue. While Guillain-Barre syndrome, Lyme disease, and sarcoidosis can cause bilateral lower motor neuron (LMN) type facial palsy, the combination of other symptoms and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy strongly favors sarcoidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis (TB) can present with fever, night sweats, and lymphadenopathy, including hilar lymphadenopathy. However, TB typically causes caseating granulomas and does not commonly present with bilateral facial nerve palsy.

 

Option C. Lymphoma: Lymphoma can also present with fever, night sweats, and lymphadenopathy. However, it typically involves systemic B symptoms and other lymph node groups. Bilateral facial nerve palsy is not a common presentation of lymphoma.

 

Option D. Hypersensitive pneumonitis: Hypersensitive pneumonitis can present with respiratory symptoms and lymphadenopathy, but it is usually associated with exposure to inhaled organic antigens. It does not typically cause systemic symptoms like fever, night sweats, and bilateral facial nerve palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with systemic symptoms like fever and night sweats and the presence of bilateral facial nerve palsy is highly suggestive of sarcoidosis. Always consider sarcoidosis first in such clinical scenarios.

questions.text: A woman presents to you with fever, arthralgia, ulcers, fatigue for the past six months, and new-onset hematuria. Urine examination reveals RBC casts and proteinuria. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lupus nephritis

 

Lupus nephritis is a common complication of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organ systems. The patient's symptoms of fever, arthralgia, ulcers, and fatigue, combined with new-onset hematuria and findings of RBC casts and proteinuria in the urine, are indicative of systemic involvement typical of lupus nephritis.

 

Lupus nephritis is characterized by inflammation of the kidneys, often leading to hematuria, proteinuria, and renal impairment.

 

Next Step -

 

Conducting an ANA (antinuclear antibody) test.

 

Performing an anti-dsDNA (anti-double stranded DNA) test, which is noted as being very specific and correlates with lupus nephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute interstitial nephritis: This condition typically presents with WBC casts rather than RBC casts in the urine and is not usually associated with systemic symptoms like fever, arthralgia, or ulcers.

 

Option B. Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN): While PSGN can cause RBC casts and proteinuria, it is generally a renal-limited condition and does not present with systemic symptoms like fever, arthralgia, and ulcers.

 

Option D. IgA nephropathy: IgA nephropathy is also a renal-limited condition and typically does not present with systemic symptoms. It is characterized by recurrent episodes of gross hematuria, usually following upper respiratory infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lupus nephritis should be suspected in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus who present with renal symptoms such as hematuria and proteinuria, especially when accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever, arthralgia, ulcers, and fatigue. Further testing, including ANA and anti-dsDNA antibodies, is warranted to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10-20 ferrous sulfate tablets. Arterial blood gas revealed acidosis. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Whole Bowel Irrigation

 

The child has ingested a significant amount of ferrous sulfate, leading to iron intoxication, which has resulted in metabolic acidosis. Managing iron overdose requires specific interventions.

 

Key Points:

 

  1. Iron Intoxication: Iron overdose is a common pediatric poisoning that can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. Ingesting a large number of ferrous sulfate tablets can result in gastrointestinal irritation, systemic toxicity, and metabolic acidosis.
  2. Arterial Blood Gas (ABG) Revealed Acidosis: Metabolic acidosis is a severe consequence of iron poisoning, indicating systemic toxicity.

 

Management of Iron Intoxication:

 

  • Whole Bowel Irrigation (WBI): This is a key intervention for decontaminating the gastrointestinal tract in cases of iron overdose. WBI is performed using a polyethylene glycol-electrolyte solution to flush out the gastrointestinal contents. It is particularly useful when iron tablets are visible on an abdominal X-ray.

 

Antidote: The specific antidote for iron poisoning is deferoxamine, which binds free iron and promotes its excretion. While deferoxamine is essential in managing iron toxicity, it is not listed as an option in this question.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Activated Charcoal: As mentioned, it is not effective for iron, alcohols, acids, alkalis, or petroleum product intoxications. Activated charcoal does not adsorb iron, making it unsuitable for treating iron overdose.

 

Option C. Dimercaprol: Used for heavy metal poisoning like arsenic, gold, and mercury, but not effective for iron.

 

Option D. Penicillamine: Used primarily for heavy metal poisoning like copper and lead, and ineffective for iron.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Whole Bowel Irrigation with polyethylene glycol is the preferred method for managing iron tablet ingestion, especially when iron tablets are visible on an abdominal X-ray.

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with a unilateral headache. It is associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. What is the best drug for acute management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sumatriptan

 

The patient's symptoms are characteristic of a migraine, which is often associated with unilateral headache, nausea, photophobia (sensitivity to light), and phonophobia (sensitivity to sound).

 

Sumatriptan: This medication is a serotonin receptor agonist (triptan) used for the acute treatment of migraine attacks. It works by stimulating serotonin (5-HT) receptors in the brain, leading to vasoconstriction of dilated blood vessels and relief from migraine symptoms.

 

The best drug for acute management of a migraine attack in this scenario is Sumatriptan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flunarizine: This is a calcium channel blocker used for the prophylactic treatment of migraine, not for acute management.

 

Option C. Propranolol: This beta-blocker is also used for migraine prophylaxis, not for acute attacks.

 

Option D. Topiramate: Used for preventing migraine, not for treating an acute attack.

 

Educaitonal Objective:

 

Sumatriptan is the best medication for the acute management of migraine, characterized by unilateral headache, nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia.

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

questions.text: A male patient presents with sensory loss and weakness of limbs for 3 months. He also has angular stomatitis. On examination, there is loss of proprioception, vibration sensations, UMN type of lower limb weakness, and absent ankle reflex. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

 

The patient presents with sensory loss, limb weakness, and specific neurological findings that are indicative of subacute combined degeneration of the cord due to vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Key Findings:

 

  1. Sensory Loss and Weakness of Limbs: This suggests a neurological disorder affecting the peripheral and central nervous systems.
  2. Angular Stomatitis: This is often associated with vitamin deficiencies, particularly vitamin B12.
  3. Loss of Proprioception and Vibration Sensation: This is characteristic of posterior column involvement, which is seen in subacute combined degeneration.
  4. UMN Type of Lower Limb Weakness: Upper motor neuron signs (UMN) such as spasticity and exaggerated reflexes, except for the absent ankle reflex, are indicative of corticospinal tract involvement.
  5. Absent Ankle Reflex: This, along with UMN signs, is a classic feature of subacute combined degeneration of the cord.

 

Subacute Combined Degeneration of the Cord: This condition is due to vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to demyelination of the posterior columns and corticospinal tracts. This results in a combination of sensory ataxia, spasticity, and other upper motor neuron signs, except for the absent ankle reflex which indicates peripheral neuropathy.

 

Additional Findings:

 

  • Angular Stomatitis: Points towards a vitamin deficiency.
  • Babinski Positivity with Absent Ankle Jerk: This combination is specifically associated with subacute combined degeneration of the cord due to B12 deficiency. Other conditions like cauda equina syndrome or Friedreich ataxia could present similarly, but the presence of angular stomatitis and the described neurological findings strongly support subacute combined degeneration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extradural Cord Compression: This would typically present with radicular pain and possibly more pronounced lower motor neuron signs below the level of compression, not the UMN signs described here.

 

Option B. Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS): ALS involves both UMN and LMN signs but does not typically present with sensory loss or specific vitamin deficiency signs like angular stomatitis.

 

Option C. Multiple Sclerosis (MS): MS can present with varied neurological signs, but it does not typically present with angular stomatitis or the classic combination of absent ankle reflex with UMN signs seen in subacute combined degeneration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subacute combined degeneration of the cord due to vitamin B12 deficiency presents with sensory loss, UMN signs in the lower limbs, and absent ankle reflex, along with other signs of vitamin deficiency like angular stomatitis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents to you with fever, breathlessness, and cough with expectoration. A CT scan was done which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Consolidation

 

The patient's symptoms of fever, breathlessness, and cough with expectoration suggest an infectious process in the lungs. The CT scan provided shows a large area of increased density (whitish patch) in the right lung, particularly in the lower lobe. This area is accompanied by air bronchograms, which are dark branching structures representing air-filled bronchi within the consolidated lung tissue. The presence of air bronchograms is a classic sign of consolidation, which indicates that the alveoli are filled with inflammatory exudates, cells, or other materials, typically due to pneumonia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mass: A mass would appear as a localized, well-defined lesion in the lung tissue without the characteristic air bronchograms seen in consolidation. It would not typically present with diffuse symptoms like those described (fever, breathlessness, and productive cough).

 

Option C. Pleural Effusion: Pleural effusion involves the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space surrounding the lungs. On imaging, it appears as a homogenous opacity at the lung base with a meniscus sign. It does not show air bronchograms and typically does not present with the same radiographic features as consolidation.

 

Option D. Diaphragmatic Hernia: A diaphragmatic hernia involves the protrusion of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity through a defect in the diaphragm. This condition would appear on imaging as abdominal organs (e.g., intestines) within the chest cavity, not as a consolidation pattern with air bronchograms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Consolidation in the lung, often due to pneumonia, is characterized by a homogenous area of increased density with air bronchograms on imaging, and presents with symptoms such as fever, breathlessness, and productive cough.

questions.text: A female patient presents with severe restlessness, palpitations, and tremors to the emergency department. She is a known case of bronchial asthma. On examination, the neck looks swollen. Blood pressure is elevated, and tachycardia is noted. ECG shows atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs is used for immediate management in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Diltiazem

 

In a patient with atrial fibrillation and bronchial asthma, the primary goal is to control the heart rate. For rate control in atrial fibrillation, beta-blockers and non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (NDCCBs) like diltiazem or verapamil are commonly used. However, in this case, the patient has bronchial asthma, which makes the use of beta-blockers (such as propranolol and esmolol) less suitable due to their potential to exacerbate asthma symptoms.

 

Diltiazem is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that effectively controls the heart rate without affecting bronchial muscle tone, making it a safer option for patients with asthma. Therefore, diltiazem is the drug of choice for immediate management in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker, which can exacerbate bronchial asthma by causing bronchoconstriction. Thus, it is not a suitable choice for patients with asthma.

 

Option C. Esmolol: Similar to propranolol, esmolol is a beta-blocker and can worsen asthma symptoms due to its bronchoconstrictive effects, making it unsuitable for this patient.

 

Option D. Propylthiouracil: This medication is used in the management of thyroid storm, a condition associated with severe hyperthyroidism. It is not relevant for rate control in atrial fibrillation and does not address the immediate needs of this patient's condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For immediate rate control in atrial fibrillation in a patient with bronchial asthma, non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers like diltiazem are preferred over beta-blockers to avoid exacerbating asthma symptoms.

questions.text: A patient with retro-positive status was started on 2nd line highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART). Which of the following can be used to monitor treatment efficacy? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Viral load

 

Viral load measurement is the primary method used to monitor the efficacy of antiretroviral therapy (ART) in patients with HIV. According to WHO and NACO guidelines, the monitoring of viral load is crucial for assessing the effectiveness of the treatment. Initially, viral load is monitored every six months until the regimen is stabilized. After that, it is monitored annually.

 

The goal of ART is to achieve an undetectable viral load, defined as less than 50 copies per mL. If the viral load is less than 50 copies, it indicates effective suppression of the virus, and the patient can continue with the same ART regimen with yearly monitoring.

 

If the viral load exceeds 1000 copies, it suggests treatment failure, necessitating a change in the ART regimen.

 

For viral loads between 50 and 1000 copies, the issue is often due to poor adherence to therapy, and it is recommended to ensure adherence and frequently monitor viral load every three months until suppression is achieved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CD4+ T cell count: Previously, CD4+ T cell count was commonly used to monitor HIV treatment. However, current guidelines prioritize viral load over CD4 count for monitoring treatment efficacy. While CD4 count is still important for assessing the immune system's health, it is not the primary marker for treatment efficacy.

 

Option C. p24 antigen: The p24 antigen is a protein associated with HIV. It is used for early detection of HIV infection but is not suitable for monitoring long-term treatment efficacy. p24 levels do not provide reliable information on viral suppression or ART effectiveness.

 

Option D. Viral serotype: Viral serotyping involves identifying different strains of HIV but does not provide information on treatment efficacy. It is more relevant in epidemiological studies and vaccine development rather than in monitoring ongoing therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viral load measurement is the most important and recommended method for monitoring the efficacy of antiretroviral therapy in HIV patients. The goal is to achieve an undetectable viral load (<50 copies/mL).

choices.text: Pathergy test is a criterion as per the ISG diagnostic criteria
Ulcers are common on the dorsum of the penis
Aphthous ulcers occur similar to Crohn’s disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct regarding Behçet's disease? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulcers are common on the dorsum of the penis

 

Behçet's disease is a chronic, multisystem vasculitis characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, ocular inflammation, skin lesions, and more. Genital ulcers in Behçet's typically occur on the scrotum in males and the vulva in females. The dorsum of the penis is rarely involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pathergy test is a criterion as per the ISG diagnostic criteria: Correct. The International Study Group (ISG) includes the pathergy test (a sterile pustule at the site of needle prick) as a supportive criterion.

 

Option C. Aphthous ulcers occur similar to Crohn’s disease: Correct. The oral ulcers of Behçet’s resemble aphthous ulcers and can be clinically indistinguishable from those seen in Crohn’s disease.

 

Option D. Bilateral pan uveitis: Correct. Ocular involvement is common and may present as anterior uveitis, posterior uveitis, or pan uveitis—often bilateral and sight-threatening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Behçet’s disease typically affects the scrotum, vulva, eyes, and oral mucosa. Ulcers on the dorsum of the penis are atypical, making option B the incorrect statement.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman reports episodes of palpitations and dizziness, particularly following physical activity such as playing tennis. She has experienced these symptoms multiple times over the last two years. ECG is taken and it is shown. Based on her presentation and the accompanying ECG findings, which of the following diagnoses is most likely? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia

 

The diagnosis of Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Dysplasia (ARVD) is based on:

 

  1. A young patient with exertional palpitations and dizziness
  2. ECG shows characteristic epsilon waves—multiple wavelet-like appearances at the J point
  3. T-wave inversions in V1–V4 indicating RV strain/dysfunction
  4. This condition involves fibro-fatty replacement of right ventricular myocardium in the "triangle of dysplasia"

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brugada syndrome: Incorrect. It typically causes arrhythmias during rest, not exertion. ECG shows characteristic ST elevation with "coved" appearance in V1–V3, not epsilon waves.

 

Option B. Uhl anomaly: Incorrect. It involves congenital absence of right ventricular musculature, which doesn't match the ECG findings or clinical presentation.

 

Option C. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy: Incorrect. ECG would show LVH with Sokolov-Lyon criteria (S in V1 + R in V5/V6 > 35mm) and septal Q waves in lateral leads.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epsilon waves on ECG are pathognomonic for ARVD, which typically presents in young people with exertional symptoms and can be a cause of sudden cardiac death, particularly common in Italy. The condition involves desmosomal mutations and progressive RV dysfunction.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of NAME syndrome? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ebstein's anomaly

 

NAME syndrome is now recognized as part of the Carney complex, which falls under Multiple Endocrine Other Organ Neoplasia (MEON). The NAME acronym stands for:

 

  • N: Nevi (blue nevi – skin manifestation)
  • A: Atrial myxoma
  • M: Myxoid neurofibroma
  • E: Ephelides (freckles)

 

Ebstein's anomaly is not a component of this syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:


NAME syndrome (now part of Carney complex) consists of Nevi (blue), Atrial myxoma, Myxoid neurofibroma, and Ephelides (freckles). Ebstein's anomaly is not a component of this syndrome.

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV patient presented with a painful lesion, as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Kaposi sarcoma

 

Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a common malignancy in patients with HIV/AIDS. It is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and typically presents as painless or painful, violaceous (purple) lesions on the skin and mucous membranes, including the oral cavity. The image shows such a lesion on the palate, which is characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma. These lesions are vascular in nature and can vary in color from red to purple, often with a raised or nodular appearance. In HIV patients, Kaposi sarcoma is an AIDS-defining condition and is often seen in those with significant immunosuppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Basal cell carcinoma: This type of skin cancer usually occurs in sun-exposed areas of the skin and rarely affects mucous membranes. It typically presents as a pearly or waxy bump, not as multiple purple lesions.

 

Option C. Malignant melanoma: While melanomas can appear as pigmented lesions, they are usually black or brown and rarely present as multiple violaceous lesions in the oral cavity.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of cancer can occur in the oral cavity but usually presents as a non-healing ulcer or a raised, firm, scaly plaque. It does not have the characteristic color and appearance of Kaposi sarcoma lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kaposi sarcoma should be suspected in HIV patients presenting with violaceous lesions on the skin or mucous membranes. It is an AIDS-defining condition associated with HHV-8 infection.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient came with complaints of chest pain, palpitation, and shortness of breath. On examination, a mid-diastolic murmur was heard, and a prominent 'a' wave was found on JVP. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Tricuspid stenosis

 

The presence of a mid-diastolic murmur and a prominent 'a' wave in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) are key indicators for diagnosing tricuspid stenosis.

 

Tricuspid Stenosis causes an obstruction to right ventricular inflow, which leads to an increase in right atrial pressure, reflected as a prominent 'a' wave in the JVP. The mid-diastolic murmur is due to the turbulent flow across the narrowed tricuspid valve during diastole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitral Stenosis: While it can cause a diastolic murmur, it typically does not cause a prominent 'a' wave in the JVP unless there is secondary pulmonary hypertension affecting the right side of the heart.

 

Option C. Mitral Regurgitation: This would cause a holosystolic murmur and, if severe enough to cause pulmonary hypertension, may indirectly cause changes in the JVP, but it does not directly cause a prominent 'a' wave.

 

Option D. Tricuspid Regurgitation: This condition causes a large 'v' wave in the JVP due to backflow of blood into the right atrium during systole, not a prominent 'a' wave.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A prominent 'a' wave in JVP and a mid-diastolic murmur are indicative of tricuspid stenosis, a condition causing right ventricular inflow obstruction.

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker came to the medicine outpatient department with complaints of upper chest discomfort and drooping of an eyelid. He also complained of pain radiating to the upper arm and a tingling sensation in the 4th and 5th digits of his left hand. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pancoast tumor

 

Pancoast tumors, also known as superior sulcus tumors, are a type of lung cancer located at the apex (top) of the lung. These tumors are particularly associated with several key clinical features and findings, especially in chronic smokers:

 

  1. Upper chest discomfort: This is a common symptom of a Pancoast tumor due to the tumor's location at the apex of the lung.
  2. Drooping of an eyelid (ptosis): This is part of Horner's syndrome, which occurs due to compression of the sympathetic nerves by the tumor. Horner's syndrome typically includes ptosis (drooping eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on the affected side of the face.
  3. Pain radiating to the upper arm and tingling sensation: These symptoms suggest involvement of the brachial plexus, a network of nerves that supplies the arm and hand. Pancoast tumors often invade or compress these nerves, leading to referred pain and sensory disturbances in the arm and hand.
  4. Chest X-ray findings: The provided chest X-ray shows a mass at the apex of the lung, which is characteristic of a Pancoast tumor.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Upper lobe pneumonia: While upper lobe pneumonia can cause chest discomfort and possibly pain, it is not associated with Horner's syndrome or brachial plexus involvement. The X-ray findings would also typically show consolidation rather than a mass.

 

Option C. Superior vena cava obstruction: This condition can cause swelling and discoloration of the face, neck, and upper extremities due to impaired blood flow. However, it does not explain the specific nerve-related symptoms like Horner's syndrome or tingling in the digits.

 

Option D. Aspergilloma: Aspergillomas are fungal balls that develop in pre-existing lung cavities, usually in patients with a history of tuberculosis or other lung diseases. They do not typically present with the neurological symptoms seen in this case, nor do they commonly cause Horner's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pancoast tumors, or superior sulcus tumors, are associated with upper chest discomfort, Horner's syndrome, and neurological symptoms in the arm due to their apical location and propensity to invade local structures such as the brachial plexus and sympathetic nerves.

questions.text: A patient presents with uveitis and sacroiliitis. What is most likely associated with it? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HLA B27

 

The presentation of uveitis along with sacroiliitis is a classic manifestation of seronegative spondyloarthropathy, which is strongly associated with HLA-B27. These conditions are characterized by:

 

  • Inflammatory back pain
  • Early morning stiffness lasting more than one hour
  • Pain and stiffness that improve with exercise and worsen with rest
  • Anterior uveitis as the most common extra-articular manifestation
  • Sacroiliitis
  • Peripheral arthritis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HLA B8: Incorrect. Associated with good prognosis in sarcoidosis, not spondyloarthropathy

 

Option C. HLA B5: Incorrect. Associated with Behçet's disease

 

Option D. HLA B51: Incorrect. Also associated with Behçet's disease

 

Educational Objective:

 

HLA-B27 is strongly associated with seronegative spondyloarthropathies, particularly when patients present with the combination of uveitis and sacroiliitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered ineffective in the prevention of COVID-19? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ivermectin

 

Ivermectin has been extensively studied during the COVID-19 pandemic but has not demonstrated any proven efficacy in preventing COVID-19 infection. Despite creating headlines during the pandemic period, clinical studies have not provided strong evidence that ivermectin reduces the risk of transmission or acquisition of COVID-19.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mask: Wearing masks has been proven to be an effective preventive measure in reducing the transmission of COVID-19 by providing a physical barrier against respiratory droplets.

 

Option B. Vaccine: Vaccines serve as pre-exposure prophylaxis and have been demonstrated to be effective in preventing severe COVID-19 infection and reducing transmission.

 

Option D. Cough etiquette: Proper cough etiquette is an important preventive measure that helps reduce the spread of respiratory droplets containing the virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ivermectin, despite being widely discussed during the pandemic, has not been proven effective in preventing COVID-19 infection, unlike established preventive measures such as masks, vaccines, and proper cough etiquette.

questions.text: According to KDIGO staging of chronic kidney disease (CKD), what is the GFR range for stage 3b? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 30–44 mL/min/1.73m²

 

Stage 3b CKD is defined by a GFR range of 30–44 mL/min/1.73m². CKD stage 3 is divided into two subcategories:

 

  • Stage 3a: GFR 45–59 mL/min/1.73m²
  • Stage 3b: GFR 30–44 mL/min/1.73m²

 

Educational Objective:

 

GFR ranges for CKD staging:

 

  • Stage 1: >90 mL/min/1.73m²
  • Stage 2: 60–89 mL/min/1.73m²
  • Stage 3a: 45–59 mL/min/1.73m²
  • Stage 3b: 30–44 mL/min/1.73m²
  • Stage 4: 15–29 mL/min/1.73m²
  • Stage 5: <15 mL/min/1.73m²

questions.text: A 23-year-old medical student with a 2-month history of palpitations, sweating, and restlessness. He also complains of a sweaty palm. His appearance is as shown in the picture. What is the next step in evaluation? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ultrasensitive thyrotropin

 

The patient's symptoms and the clinical image strongly suggest Graves' Orbitopathy (also known as Graves' Ophthalmopathy), characterized by proptosis, eyelid edema, and eye congestion. The most common cause of both unilateral and bilateral exophthalmos is Graves' disease, an autoimmune disorder leading to hyperthyroidism.

 

The next step in evaluating a patient suspected of having hyperthyroidism is to perform a thyroid function test (TFT), with the most important initial test being the measurement of Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH). The ultrasensitive thyrotropin test, which measures TSH levels, is crucial because it helps in determining the presence of hyperthyroidism.

 

In Graves' disease, TSH levels are typically very low or undetectable, while free T4 and Total T3 levels are elevated (primary hyperthyroidism).

 

IOC – MRI of the orbit

 

TOC – mild – moderate disease – conservative management

 

Mod.-severe disease – first line TOC – CS (Dexamethasone); Teprotumumab (IGF1 receptor inhibitor Mab)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyroid receptor antibody: This test is specific for confirming Graves' disease, but it is not the first step. It is used after initial thyroid function tests suggest hyperthyroidism to confirm the diagnosis. The antibodies known as TRAb (TSH receptor antibody/ Thyroid receptor Ab).

 

2 forms of TRAb – TSI (Thyroid Stimulating Immunoglobulin) and

                -  TBII (Thyroid binding Inhibitory Immunoglobulin)

 

Option B. Radioactive Iodine Uptake: This test helps to differentiate between various causes of hyperthyroidism, such as Graves' disease and toxic multinodular goiter. It is not the first step but follows initial thyroid function tests if hyperthyroidism is confirmed.

 

Option D. Anti thyroid peroxidase antibody: This antibody is not specific for Graves' disease. It is more commonly associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and other autoimmune thyroid disorders, making it less relevant for initial evaluation in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first and most crucial test in the evaluation of suspected hyperthyroidism, such as in a case suggestive of Graves' disease, is the measurement of ultrasensitive thyrotropin (TSH) levels.

 

Confirmatory Diagnosis – by TRAbs (Thyroid receptor antibodies)

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the initial recommended test for diagnosing pheochromocytoma? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 24 hr urinary total metanephrines

 

The 24-hour urinary metanephrines test is considered the gold standard and first-line test for diagnosing pheochromocytoma in the general population. The test should include fractionated catecholamines for comprehensive evaluation. This test is preferred due to its high sensitivity and specificity in detecting these rare neuroendocrine tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MIBG scan: This is a nuclear medicine imaging test that can be useful for localizing pheochromocytoma and ruling out multifocal or metastatic disease, but it's not the initial diagnostic test. It's typically performed after biochemical confirmation of the disease.

 

Option C. Plasma catecholamines: While plasma catecholamines can be measured as part of the routine testing, they are not as reliable as urinary metanephrines due to their fluctuating levels and potential for false positives.

 

Option D. MRI of the whole abdomen: This is an imaging study used for tumor localization after biochemical confirmation of pheochromocytoma. It's not appropriate as an initial diagnostic test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A 24-hour urinary metanephrines test with fractionated catecholamines is the initial recommended test for diagnosing pheochromocytoma in the general population. Plasma metanephrines can be considered in high-risk populations (such as those with a family history or genetic syndromes).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP)? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thrombosis

 

TTP is characterized by a pentad of clinical findings:

 

  1. Fever
  2. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia with schistocytes/helmet cells
  3. Thrombocytopenia
  4. Renal failure
  5. Neurological involvement

 

TTP is caused by ADAMTS13 deficiency, which leads to excessive formation of platelet microthrombi in small vessels. While microvascular thrombosis occurs, macrovascular thrombosis is not a defining feature of TTP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic pentad of TTP consists of fever, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, renal failure, and neurological involvement. Macrovascular thrombosis is not a defining feature of TTP, unlike in conditions such as antiphospholipid syndrome, where both macro- and microvascular thrombosis can occur.

questions.text: Which mutation is seen in sickle cell disease? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glu → Val (6)

 

Sickle cell disease is caused by a specific point mutation at position 6 of the β-globin chain, where glutamic acid (Glu) is replaced by valine (Val). This single amino acid substitution leads to the formation of abnormal hemoglobin S (HbS), which polymerizes under deoxygenated conditions, causing red blood cells to become sickle-shaped.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cell disease is caused by a point mutation at position 6 of the β-globin chain, where glutamic acid (Glu) is replaced by valine (Val).

questions.text: Features of MEN2B are all except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Parathyroid hyperplasia

 

MEN2B syndrome is characterized by a distinct set of clinical features known as the "4 M's":

 

  1. Marfanoid body habitus
  2. Mucosal neuromas
  3. Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC)
  4. Megacolon (Hirschsprung disease)

 

Additionally, pheochromocytoma is also a feature of MEN2B. The syndrome is caused by mutations in the RET proto-oncogene located on chromosome 10.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parathyroid hyperplasia is NOT a component of MEN2B syndrome, while the characteristic features include medullary thyroid carcinoma, mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, and megacolon (the 4 M's).

choices.text: Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.text: What causes decrease in GFR? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decrease in glomerular filtration coefficient

 

The glomerular filtration coefficient (Kf) is directly proportional to GFR according to the formula. Therefore, a decrease in Kf will lead to a decrease in GFR. The filtration coefficient represents the product of the hydraulic permeability and surface area available for filtration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure: Incorrect. A decrease in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure will increase GFR by increasing the net filtration pressure gradient.

 

Option B. Increase in glomerular hydrostatic pressure: Incorrect. An increase in glomerular hydrostatic pressure increases GFR by promoting filtration.

 

Option D. Decrease in glomerular oncotic pressure: Incorrect. A decrease in glomerular oncotic pressure increases GFR by reducing the opposition to filtration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glomerular filtration coefficient (Kf) and GFR are directly proportional, meaning a decrease in Kf causes a decrease in GFR.

questions.text: Which of the following would most likely lead to a decrease in the intensity of the murmur in a patient with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Squatting

 

In hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), the intensity of the murmur is influenced by the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. Various maneuvers and medications can affect this obstruction by altering preload (the volume of blood in the ventricles before contraction) or afterload (the resistance the heart must pump against).

 

Squatting increases preload by squeezing the peripheral veins and increasing venous return to the heart. This increase in preload reduces LVOT obstruction, thereby decreasing the murmur's intensity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Digoxin: Digoxin increases contractility. In HCM, increased contractility can worsen LVOT obstruction, thereby increasing the intensity of the murmur and worsening the murmur.

 

Option C. Valsalva: The Valsalva maneuver reduces preload by decreasing venous return to the heart. This reduction in preload can increase LVOT obstruction, leading to a louder murmur.

 

Option D. Furosemide: By reducing preload, furosemide increases LVOT obstruction and murmur intensity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increasing preload (e.g., through squatting) reduces LVOT obstruction in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, leading to a decrease in the murmur's intensity.

questions.text: Match the following hormones to receptors: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C

 

  • (1-B) Acetylcholine works through ligand-gated channels (like other neurotransmitters such as serotonin and GABA)
  • (2-A) Insulin functions via the receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) pathway, with insulin receptor substrate (IRS) as its substrate
  • (3-D) Growth hormone operates through the JAK-STAT pathway (non-receptor tyrosine kinase pathway)
  • (4-C) Thyroxine, being lipid-soluble, acts through nuclear receptors

 

Educational Objective:

 

The distinct receptor mechanisms for different hormone classes:

 

  • Acetylcholine → Ligand-gated channels
  • Insulin → Tyrosine kinase pathway
  • Growth hormone → JAK-STAT pathway
  • Thyroxine → Nuclear receptors

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient complained of bilateral lower limb numbness. He has a history of low BP and gastrectomy done for gastric cancer a year back. On examination, Romberg test is positive and there is loss of proprioception in both lower limbs. Which of the following deficiency can cause this condition? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

This patient's presentation strongly suggests Vitamin B12 deficiency for several reasons:

 

  1. History of gastrectomy – Loss of stomach leads to loss of intrinsic factor, essential for B12 absorption
  2. Neurological symptoms – Bilateral lower limb numbness
  3. Positive Romberg test and loss of proprioception indicate posterior column involvement, which is characteristic of subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord seen in B12 deficiency
  4. The combination of gastrectomy and neurological symptoms is classic for B12 deficiency

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B6 deficiency: While it can cause peripheral neuropathy, it doesn't typically cause posterior column signs

 

Option C. Thiamine deficiency: Primarily causes Wernicke's encephalopathy and cardiovascular symptoms; doesn't typically present with proprioception loss; more commonly seen in alcoholics

 

Option D. Folic acid deficiency: Primarily causes hematological manifestations; does not cause neurological symptoms like B12 deficiency

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrectomy leads to B12 deficiency due to loss of intrinsic factor, and B12 deficiency can cause subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, presenting with posterior column signs (proprioception loss and positive Romberg test).

questions.text:
A patient presents to you with fever, jaundice, and malaise. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the serology reports given below? (NEET PG 2023)

 

  • Anti-HBc (IgM): Positive
  • HBsAg: Positive
  • Anti-HBs: Negative
  • Anti-HCV antibodies: Negative
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Acute hepatitis B

 

The serology results provide crucial information for diagnosing the type of hepatitis the patient has:

 

  1. HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): Positive
    • This indicates an active hepatitis B infection, as HBsAg is a marker of infection.
  2. Anti-HBc (IgM) (Hepatitis B core antibody, IgM): Positive
    • The presence of IgM anti-HBc indicates a recent infection or acute hepatitis B. IgM is produced early in the infection and suggests that the infection is recent.
  3. Anti-HBs (Hepatitis B surface antibody): Negative
    • The absence of anti-HBs indicates that the patient has not resolved the infection or been vaccinated. In the context of acute infection, this is expected as the patient has not yet developed immunity.
  4. Anti-HCV antibodies: Negative
    • This indicates that the patient does not have hepatitis C.

 

Based on these results, the diagnosis is acute hepatitis B. The presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc are key indicators of an acute infection.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Acute hepatitis C: This is ruled out by the negative anti-HCV antibodies.

 

Option C. Chronic hepatitis B: Chronic hepatitis B is diagnosed when HBsAg persists for more than six months and is typically associated with IgG anti-HBc, not IgM.

 

Option D. Chronic hepatitis C: This is ruled out by the negative anti-HCV antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc in a patient with fever, jaundice, and malaise strongly indicates acute hepatitis B.

questions.text: Among the given options, murmur given in the image is associated with? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mitral Regurgitation

 

The image provided indicates a murmur occurring between S1 and S2, which is described as a pan-systolic murmur. This type of murmur spans the entirety of systole.

 

Mitral Regurgitation produces a pan-systolic murmur due to the backward flow of blood from the left ventricle into the left atrium throughout systole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic Regurgitation: Characterized by an early diastolic murmur due to backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle.

 

Option C. Mitral Stenosis: Characterized by a mid-diastolic murmur due to obstructed blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle during diastole.

 

Option D. Aortic Stenosis: Characterized by an ejection systolic murmur due to turbulent blood flow across a narrowed aortic valve during systole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitral regurgitation is associated with a pan-systolic murmur, which is present throughout the systole and heard between the S1 and S2 heart sounds.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is non-compliant with medication presents to you with sudden onset breathlessness. A chest X-ray was done, which is shown below. How will you manage this patient? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intravenous nitroglycerin

 

The patient presents with symptoms and signs indicative of pulmonary edema, which is evident from the chest X-ray showing interstitial edema and classic bat-wing appearance, suggestive of cardiogenic pulmonary edema. The history of hypertension and non-compliance with medication supports the diagnosis, as poorly controlled hypertension can lead to increased afterload, left ventricular failure, and subsequent pulmonary edema.

 

Intravenous nitroglycerin: Nitroglycerin is the treatment of choice in this scenario as it helps to reduce both preload and afterload by dilating veins and arteries. This leads to a reduction in pulmonary congestion and improvement in symptoms of breathlessness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous salbutamol: Salbutamol is a bronchodilator used primarily in the treatment of asthma or COPD exacerbations, and primarily not used intravenously. It is not indicated for managing pulmonary edema and does not address the underlying cause of fluid accumulation in the lungs.

 

Option C. Nebulization with salbutamol: Similar to intravenous salbutamol, nebulized salbutamol is used for bronchodilation in conditions like asthma or COPD. It is not effective in treating pulmonary edema and does not relieve the symptoms caused by fluid overload in the lungs.

 

Option D. Oxygen and antibiotics: While oxygen might be necessary to support the patient’s respiratory status, antibiotics are not indicated unless there is a concurrent infection, which is not suggested by the patient’s presentation. The primary issue here is fluid overload due to heart failure, not an infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of cardiogenic pulmonary edema, intravenous nitroglycerin is essential to reduce preload and afterload, thereby alleviating pulmonary congestion and improving the patient's symptoms.

questions.text: High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA) is not caused by: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diarrhea

 

Diarrhea causes Normal Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA), not High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA). There are only three main causes of NAGMA, remembered by the mnemonic "DRS":

 

  • D: Diarrhea
  • R: RTA (Renal Tubular Acidosis – types 1, 2, and 4)
  • S: Saline administration (causing hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA): Incorrect. DKA is a classic cause of HAGMA. It leads to accumulation of ketone bodies, causing high anion gap.

 

Option C. Acute renal failure: Incorrect. Renal failure causes HAGMA due to accumulation of organic acids and decreased acid excretion.

 

Option D. Inborn errors of metabolism: Incorrect. Most inborn errors of metabolism cause HAGMA through accumulation of organic acids.

 

The causes of HAGMA can be remembered using the mnemonic "GOLDMARK":

 

  • G: Glycol (ethylene glycol)
  • O: Oxoproline (paracetamol metabolite)
  • L: L-lactate
  • D: D-lactate (short bowel syndrome)
  • M: Methanol
  • A: Aspirin
  • R: Renal failure
  • K: Ketoacidosis (diabetic, alcoholic, starvation)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diarrhea causes Normal Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA), not High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA).

questions.text: Which of the following viruses spreads predominantly through water? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HAV (Hepatitis A Virus)

 

Hepatitis A virus (HAV) primarily spreads through the fecal-oral route and contaminated water. It is one of the main viral pathogens that uses water as its predominant transmission route. The virus is highly stable in water and sewage, making waterborne transmission a significant public health concern, especially in areas with poor sanitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HCV (Hepatitis C Virus): Incorrect because HCV spreads predominantly through the parenteral route, particularly through needlestick injuries, blood transfusions, and surgical procedures.

 

Option C. HDV (Hepatitis D Virus): Incorrect because HDV is a dependent virus that requires the presence of HBV for its replication and transmission. It cannot spread independently through water.

 

Option D. HBV (Hepatitis B Virus): Incorrect because HBV primarily spreads through vertical transmission (mother to child) in developing countries like India. While sexual transmission is possible, it's relatively rare. It does not spread through water.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis A virus spreads predominantly through the fecal-oral route and contaminated water, unlike other hepatitis viruses, which have different primary modes of transmission.

questions.text:
Which of the following findings are typically associated with glomerular hematuria? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Brown urine
  2. Dysuria absent
  3. Crystals in urine
  4. Edema is rare
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, B

 

Glomerular hematuria has specific characteristics that help differentiate it from non-glomerular causes:

 

A. Brown urine: Brown/cola-colored urine is typical of glomerular hematuria due to the presence of RBCs.

 

B. Dysuria absent: Absence of dysuria is characteristic, as there is no urinary tract inflammation or infection.

 

These findings together strongly suggest glomerular origin of hematuria.

 

Other Options:

 

C. Crystals in urine: Incorrect. Crystalluria is not a feature of glomerular hematuria. Instead, findings like dysmorphic RBCs, acanthocytes, or RBC casts are characteristic.

 

D. Edema is rare: Incorrect. Edema is common in glomerular diseases, whether nephritic or nephrotic, due to:

 

  • Loss of albumin leading to decreased oncotic pressure
  • Activation of the renin-angiotensin system
  • Underlying inflammatory processes

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glomerular hematuria includes brown/cola-colored urine and absence of dysuria, while presence of edema and absence of urinary crystals are other important characteristics.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with fever, thrombocytopenia, and hematuria. The mother tells you that the baby also suffered from bloody diarrhea a few days back. Which is likely microorganism to be isolated from the stool sample? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E. coli O157:H7

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) based on the triad of:

 

  • Hematuria
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • History of bloody diarrhea

 

E. coli O157:H7, also known as Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC) or Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC), is the most common causative organism of HUS, particularly in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Shigella flexneri

 

  • Incorrect because while it can cause bloody diarrhea, it is more commonly associated with reactive arthritis rather than HUS.
  • Does not typically cause the combination of hematuria and thrombocytopenia.

 

Option C. Salmonella enteritis

 

  • Incorrect as it is primarily associated with osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell disease.
  • Not typically associated with HUS.

 

Option D. Aeromonas

 

  • Incorrect as it typically causes simple diarrhea without the complications of HUS.
  • Does not produce Shiga toxin, which is responsible for HUS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

E. coli O157:H7 is the most common cause of Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome in children, typically presenting with bloody diarrhea followed by the triad of hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.

choices.text: Not associated with rise in Creatinine

questions.text: Acute graft rejection in a kidney transplant patient is indicated by: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Any rise in creatinine

 

In modern transplant medicine, acute graft rejection often presents subtly due to powerful immunosuppression regimens. The most common presentation of acute rejection in current clinical practice is an asymptomatic rise in serum creatinine. According to the definition, there should be at least a 25% increase in serum creatinine to diagnose acute rejection. However, in cases where antibody-mediated rejection (ABMR) is suspected, any rise in serum creatinine can lead to a diagnosis or at least a suspicion of acute rejection.

 

Other Options:
